University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: ¶ Fabula Momalio Descām Maria ~
Lord our lord thi name how mvelous
is in this large world y spred qd she
for not only thy lawd precious
ꝑper/parformed is by men of dignite
but bi u mouthe of childrēm thi bounte
ꝑper/parformed is / for in the brest sokyng
som tyme shewen thei thi heryyng
¶ Wher for in lawde as y best can or may
of the and of thi lilie flour
which that the bare ⁊and is a mayde alway
to tell a story y woll do my labour
not that y may encresse her honour
for she her self is honour ⁊and the rote
of bounte / next herᵒ sone ⁊and soules bote
¶ O mod maide . o mayde moder fre
o bush vnbrent brennyng in Moyses sight
that raveshedest doun from þᵉ Deite
thurgh þⁱ humblenes þᵉ goost þᵗat in þᵉ light
of whos vertu whan he thyn hert light
conceyued was þᵉ fadres sapience
help me to telle it in thy reủer/reence
¶ Lady thi bounte thy magnificence
thi vertu and thy humilite
ther may no tonge expresse in no science
for som tyme lady or men pᵃy to the
thu goost be fore of thy benignite
and getest vs the light of thi pᵃyer
to gyden vs vnto thi sone so dere
¶ My konnyng . is so weike o blisful quene
for to declare thi gret worthynesse
that y ne may not þᵉ weight not sustene
but as a child of twelf month old or lesse
that can vnnethe any word expresse
right so fare y and ther for y the pᵃy
gide my song that y shall of the say
¶ Ther was in Asie a gret Citee
amonges cristen folk a Iewery
susteyned by a lord of that contree
for foule vsurie ⁊and lucre vilony
hatefull to Crist ⁊and to his cōmpanye
and thurgh this strete me myght ride ⁊and wende
for it was fre ⁊and open at oyther ende
¶ A litell scole of cristen folk þ̉er/re stode
doun atte fertger ende in which þ̉er/re wer
children an hepe comen of cristen blode
that lerned in that scole yer by yere
soche man doctrine as men vsed ther
this is to seyn to syngen to rede
as smale children doıı̄un in her childhede
¶ Among thes children was a widowes sone
a litell clergion by yer of age
that day by day to scole was his wone
and eke also wher as he sey þᵉ ymage
of Cristes mod had he in vsage
as hym was taught to knele a doun ⁊and sey
his Aue marie as he goth by the wey
¶ Thus hath þˢ widow her litel sone y taught
our blisful lady Cristes moder dere
to worshipe ay ⁊and he forgate it nought
for sely child wold alway sone lere
but ay whan y remembre on þˢ mater
Synt Nicholas stant eủer/re in my psence
for he so yong to Crist dud reuerence
¶ This litell child his litel boke lernyng
as he sate in the scole at his pⁱrimere
he Alma redemptoris herd syng
as childer lerned her antiphoner
and as he durst drow hym ner ⁊and ner
and herkened ay þᵉ wordes ⁊and the note
till he the first vers coude al bi rote
¶ Nat wist he what þˢ latyn was to sey
for he so yonge ⁊and tendre was of age
but on a day his felow gan he pᵃy
expone hym this song in his langage
or tell hym whi this song was in vsage
this pᵃyed he hym to construe ⁊and declare
ful ofte tymes vpon his knees bare
¶ His felawe which þᵉ elder was than he
answerd thus this song y haue herd sey
was maked of our blessid lady fre
her to salue and her for to prey
to ben our help ⁊and socour whan we dey
y can no more expond in this mater
y lerne song y can but smal gramer
¶ And is this song maked in reủer/reence
of Cristes moder seid this Innocent
now certes y woll do my diligence
to konne it all or Cristesmasse be went
thogh þᵗat y for my pⁱrimer shal be shent
and shall be beten thryes in an houre
y woll it konne our lady to honoure
¶ His felawe taught hym homward pⁱriuely
fro day to day til he coude it by rote
and than he sang it well ⁊and boldely
fro word to word accordyng to þᵉ note
twyes a day it passed thurgh his throte
to scoleward ⁊and homward whan he went
on Cristes Moder set was his entent
¶ As y haue seid thurgh out the iewerye
this litell child as he come to ⁊and froo
full merily wold he synge ⁊and crie
o alma redemptoris euer moo
the swetnes his herte perced so
of Cristes moder that to her to pᵃy
he can not stynt of syngyng by þᵉ way
¶ Our first foo the serpent Sathanas
that hath in iewes hert his waspes nest
vp swall ⁊and seyd o Ebrayke peple alas .
ys this to yow a thyng þᵗat is honest
that soche a boy shall walke as hy lyst
in yʳo despite and synge of soche sentence
which is ageyns our lawes reuerence
¶ Fro thens forth the iewes han cōmspired
this Innocent out of this world to chace
an homycide ther to han thei hired
that in an Aley had a pⁱriue place
and as þᵉ child gan forth by for to pace
this cursed iewe hym hent ⁊and held hy fast
and kytt his throte ⁊and in a pytt hy cast
¶ Y sey þᵗat in a wardrope thei hym drewe
wher as thes Iewes purgen her entrayle
o cursed folke of herodes all newe
what may yʳo evell entent yow availe
mordre woll out certayn it wol not faile
and namely þ̉er/re as þᵉ honour of god shal sprede
the blode out crieth on your cursed dede
¶ O martir sented to virginite
now maist þᵘ syngen folwyng eủer/re in one
the white lambe celestiall qd she
of which þᵉ gret euᵃngelist Seynt Iohn
In Pathmos wrote which seith þᵗat thei gon
be fore this lambe ⁊and syng a song al newe
þᵗat neủer/re flesshly wōmman thei ne knewe
¶ This pore wydowe awaiteth al þᵉ nyght
after her litel child but he come noght
for þᵉ which assone as it is dayes light
wᵗith face pale of drede ⁊and besy thoght
she hath at scole ⁊and els wher hy soght
till fynally she gan so fer aspie
that he last seyn was in þᵉ Iewerie
¶ Wᵗith modres pite in her brest enclosed
she goth as she wer half out of her mynde
to euery place wher she hath supposed
by likelyhed her litell child to fynde
And eủer/re on Cristes mod meke ⁊and kynde
she cried ⁊and atte last thus she wroght
Amonge þᵉ cursed Iewes she hy sought
¶ She frayneth and prayeth pitously
to eủer/rey Iewe þᵗat dwelt in thilke place
to telle her if her child wentt oght forth by
thei seid nay / but Ihıı̄un of his grace
ysaue in her thoght wᵗith in a litell space
that in that place aft̉er/re her sone she cryde
wher he was casten in a pytt be syde
¶ O gret god that ꝑper/parformed thi laude
by mouth of Innocenteȝ lo her þⁱ myght
this gēmme of chastite this Emeraude
and eke of martirdome þᵉ ruby bright
ther he wᵗith throte y corven lay vpright
he Alma Redemptoris gan to synge
so lowde þᵗat all the place gan rynge
¶ The Cristen folke þᵗat thurgh þᵉ stret went
yn comen for to wondre vpon þˢ thyng
and hastely thei for þᵉ ꝓprovost sent
he come anon wᵗith out any taryng
and heryeth Crist þᵗat is of heuen kyng
and eke his moder honʳo of mankynde
and aft̉er/re that þᵉ iewes lete he bynde
¶ This childe wᵗith pitous lamentacion
Vp taken was syngyng his song alway
and wᵗith honoue ⁊and gret ꝓprocession
thei carien hym vnto þᵉ next Abbay
his mod sownyng by his bere lay
Vnnethe myght þᵉ peple þᵗat was there
this newe Rachell bryng fro his bere
¶ Wᵗith tʳment ⁊and wᵗith shameful deth echon
this ꝓprovost doth the Iewes for to sterve
that of this martir wist ⁊and þᵗat anon
he nolde no soche cursednes obserue
yvell shall he haue þᵗat evell wol deʆser/sirue
ther for wᵗith wilde horse he dud hem drawe
and after þᵗat he heng hem by þᵉ lawe
¶ Apon this bere ay lith this Innocent
be fore the chef auter while þᵉ masse last
and after þᵗat the Abbate wᵗith his couent
han sped ham for to bury hym ful fast
and whan thei holi wat̉er/re on hym cast
yet spake þˢ child whan sprong was holi wat̉er/re
and song o Alma redēmptoris mater
¶ This Abbat which þᵗat was an holy man
as monkes ben or els aughten be
this yong child cōmiure he be gan
and seid o dere child y halse the
in the vertu of the holy Trinite
tell what is þⁱ cause for to synge
sith þⁱ throte is kut to my semynge
¶ My throte is kut vnto my nekbon
seid this child ⁊and as by way of kynde
y shuld haue dyed long tyme a gon
but Ihu Crist as ye in bokes fynde
woll that his glorie laste ⁊and be in mynde
and for the worship of his moder dere
yett may y syng o Alma lowde ⁊and clere
¶ This well of mercy Cristes mod9 swete
y loued alway as after my konnynge
and whan þᵗat y my lyf shuld for lete
to me she came ⁊and bade me for to synge
this Anteme verrely in my deynge
as ye han herd / ⁊and whan þᵗat y had songe
me thoght she layd a greyn vpon my tonge
¶ Wher for y synge ⁊and syng y mote certeyne
in honoᵘur of that blisfull mayden fre
till fro my tonge taken is þᵉ greyne
and afterward this seyd she to me
my litell child now wol y fecche the
when þᵗat the greyn is fro thi tonge y take
be not a garst y will the not forsake
¶ This holy monk þᵉ Abbat hym mene y
his tonge out caught ⁊and toke away þᵉ greyn
and he yeaue vp the goost ful softely
and whan þˢ Abbat had this wond9 seyn
his salt teris trilled doun as reyn
and gruffell he fell al plat vpon þᵉ gᵒunde
and stille he lay as he had lay y bounde
¶ The couent lay eke on the pavyment
wepyng ⁊and worshipyng Crist̉er/re mod9 dere
and after thei risen ⁊and forth ben went
and toke away this martir from þᵉ bere
And in a tumbe of marbell ston clere
enclosen thei his litell body swete
ther he is now god leve vs for to mete
¶ O yong hugh of lyncolne slayn al so
wᵗith cursed Iewes as it is notable
for it is but a litell while ago
pᵃy eke for vs we synfull folk vnstable
that of his mercy god so mcyable
on vs his gret mercy he multiplye
for reuerence of his mod9 Marie
